journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of the American Heart Association: Cardiovascular and Cerebrovascular Disease

title-group.article-title: Effect of Adapted Mindfulness Training in Participants With Elevated Office Blood Pressure: The MB‐BP Study: A Randomized Clinical Trial
title-group.alt-title: Mindfulness Training for Blood Pressure Reduction

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Hypertension is a leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Despite availability of effective lifestyle and medication treatments, blood pressure (BP) is poorly controlled in the United States. Mindfulness training may offer a novel approach to improve BP control. The objective was to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction (MB‐BP) versus enhanced usual care control on unattended office systolic BP.

sec.title: Methods and Results
sec.p: Methods included a parallel‐group phase 2 randomized clinical trial conducted from June 2017 to November 2020. Follow‐up time was 6 months. Outcome assessors and data analyst were blinded to group allocation. Participants had elevated unattended office BP (≥120/80 mm Hg). We randomized 201 participants to MB‐BP (n=101) or enhanced usual care control (n=100). MB‐BP is a mindfulness‐based program adapted for elevated BP. Loss‐to‐follow‐up was 17.4%. The primary outcome was change in unattended office systolic BP at 6 months. A total of 201 participants (58.7% women; 81.1% non‐Hispanic White race and ethnicity; mean age, 59.5 years) were randomized. Results showed that MB‐BP was associated with a 5.9‐mm Hg reduction (95% CI, −9.1 to −2.8 mm Hg) in systolic BP from baseline and outperformed the control group by 4.5 mm Hg at 6 months (95% CI, −9.0 to −0.1 mm Hg) in prespecified analyses. Plausible mechanisms with evidence to be impacted by MB‐BP versus control were sedentary activity (−350.8 sitting min/wk [95% CI, −636.5 to −65.1] sitting min/wk), Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet (0.32 score [95% CI, −0.04 to 0.67]), and mindfulness (7.3 score [95% CI, 3.0–11.6]).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A mindfulness‐based program adapted for individuals with elevated BP showed clinically relevant reductions in systolic BP compared with enhanced usual care. Mindfulness training may be a useful approach to improve BP.

sec.title: Registration
sec.p: URL: https://www.clinicaltrials.gov; Unique identifiers: NCT03256890 and NCT03859076.

institution-wrap.institution: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health

fn.p: This article was sent to Pamela N. Peterson, MD, Deputy Editor, for review by expert referees, editorial decision, and final disposition.
For Sources of Funding and Disclosures, see page 11.

list-item.p: This study represents the first randomized controlled trial of a mindfulness‐based program that has been customized to participants with elevated blood pressure.

This study demonstrated a clinically significant reduction in systolic blood pressure, with evidence of effects on sedentary activity, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension dietary pattern, and mindfulness.
This program may offer an appealing approach to help control blood pressure of the 46% of Americans with hypertension, of which >75% is uncontrolled.

body.p: Hypertension is a leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), and CVD is the primary cause of mortality worldwide.1 Hypertension is a major preventable risk factor for CVD,2 but 46% of Americans have hypertension,3 and of them, <25% have it controlled.2, 4, 5 Despite numerous effective lifestyle and medication treatments, hypertension control has worsened in recent years. Specifically, the nationally representative National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey evaluated temporal trends in controlled blood pressure (BP), defined as systolic BP (SBP) <140 mm Hg and diastolic BP (DBP) <90 mm Hg in adults who had been told by a physician or other health care professional that they had hypertension or high BP. Analyses showed that among all adults with hypertension, age‐adjusted reductions in controlled BP decreased from 52.8% (95% CI, 50.0–55.7) during the years 2009 through 2012, to 48.2% (95% CI, 45.7–50.8) during the years 2017 through 2020.4, 5 In the years 2017 to 2020, <25% of US adults with hypertension had controlled BP when defined by the 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guideline recommendations of SBP <130 mm Hg and DBP <80 mm Hg.5, 6 Worsening BP control suggests the need to either improve adherence to evidence‐based treatments, such as antihypertensive medication and lifestyle modifications (eg, diet and physical activity), or consider alternative treatment approaches.2, 4 Mindfulness training offers promise to improve adherence to evidence‐based medical regimens and could offer a novel treatment approach.

Mindfulness involves the self‐regulation of attention so that it is maintained on immediate experience and adopting a particular orientation towards one's experiences in the present moment, characterized by curiosity, openness, and acceptance.7 Mindfulness also involves remembering to bring one's wisdom into the present moment.8, 9 Wisdom in the context of elevated BP can include knowledge that evidence‐based practices, such as physical activity, diet, limited alcohol consumption, and antihypertensive medication adherence, can improve well‐being. Evidence is emerging about the impact of mindfulness‐based programs on BP control. For example, in a systematic review and meta‐analysis of 8 studies, SBP was reduced by 6.6 (95% CI, −11.7 to −1.5) mm Hg in participants who received a mindfulness‐based program compared with control at immediate postintervention.10 However, prior studies were limited by typically having small sample sizes, modest generalizability, and short‐term follow‐up.10 Furthermore, prior trials tested mindfulness‐based programs that were not adapted to patients with high BP.10 We hypothesized that a mindfulness‐based program that was adapted to direct the mindfulness skills of attention control, self‐awareness, and emotion regulation to patients' relationship with diet, physical activity, alcohol consumption, stress reactivity, and antihypertensive medication adherence would result in clinically significant reductions in BP compared with enhanced usual care. The theoretical framework is described elsewhere11, 12 and shown in Figure S1. We also hypothesized that the adapted mindfulness training would result in improved health behaviors that are relevant to BP control, such as physical activity, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) dietary pattern, alcohol consumption, and antihypertensive medication use.

sec.title: Study Design, Setting, and Participants
sec.p: The MB‐BP (Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction) Study was a parallel‐group, phase 2, randomized clinical trial (RCT) comparing group‐based mindfulness meditation training adapted to determinants of BP versus an enhanced usual care control. Participants were enrolled and assessed from June 2017 to November 2020 through advertising in the local community and referral from clinicians. The trial was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov at the onset of participant recruitment (applied in July 2017, approved in August 2017) and before outcome assessment in participants. Data were not examined before registration.

Inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) elevated unattended office BP (ie, SBP ≥120 mm Hg or DBP ≥80 mm Hg)6 and (2) adulthood (aged ≥18 years). Exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) current regular meditation practice (greater than once/week); (2) inability to communicate in English; (3) serious medical illness precluding regular class attendance; (4) current substance use disorder, suicidal ideation, or eating disorder; and (5) history of bipolar or psychotic disorders or self‐injurious behaviors.13 The study protocol was approved by the institutional review board at Brown University (protocol number 1412001171) on June 12, 2017. All participants provided written informed consent.

This study combined 2 unanalyzed, preregistered, clinical trials with identical methods that were part of a larger study. Specifically, the study received funding through a National Institutes of Health UH2/UH3 cooperative agreement that provided an initial 3 years of funding (UH2 phase), followed by an application for 2 additional years of funding (UH3 phase). During the UH2 phase, we proposed and conducted a single‐arm pilot MB‐BP Study that has been reported elsewhere.11 We were encouraged to shift from a single‐arm trial to an RCT before the UH3 phase, which we did, preregistering the trial on clincialtrials.gov. That trial identified SBP at 6‐month follow‐up as the primary outcome (number NCT03256890). As we applied to the UH3 phase, we were required to create a new clinicaltrials.gov registration focused on mechanisms of behavior change (we selected interoceptive awareness and DASH diet; number NCT03256890), to be consistent with the Science of Behavior Change model that tests engagement of interventions with hypothesized mechanisms first and then tests the degree to which a change in the mechanism translates into behavior change.14, 15 We planned to combine both data sets for meta‐analyses, as the clinical trial methods were identical. We shifted to the UH3 phase before gathering an adequately powered sample for SBP as the primary outcome. As such, to maximize statistical power, the current study analyzed data across the 2 identical RCTs performed in sequence during the UH2 and UH3 phases. Findings on the DASH dietary pattern and interoceptive awareness will be reported in detail elsewhere.16 Limitations of this approach are described in the Discussion section.

sec.title: Blinding and Randomization
sec.p: Eligible participants who completed their baseline assessments were randomized (1:1) to receive either the MB‐BP program or control condition. Randomization was stratified within sex and BP status (ie, SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg versus SBP 120–139 mm Hg and DBP <90 mm Hg). Randomization occurred ≈1 week before the beginning of each cycle of group MB‐BP classes, and participants were informed within 24 hours after randomization. Randomization was performed by a researcher (EBL) blinded to participant identification using Research Randomizer (Version 4.0). The senior project manager (FBS) notified participants of randomization results. Staff (WRN) conducting follow‐up activities were blinded to group allocation, with the exception of adverse events relatedness inquiry, which was completed by a separate staff member. The data analyst was (MMS) blinded to group allocation.

sec.title: Intervention Descriptions and Theoretical Framework
sec.p: MB‐BP is based on, and time‐matched to, the standardized Mindfulness‐Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) program.11 Both consist of a group orientation session, eight 2.5‐hour weekly group sessions, and a 7.5‐hour 1‐day group session. Recommended home mindfulness practice was ≥45 min/d, 6 d/wk. The unique areas of MB‐BP, described in detail in Data S1, Table S1, and elsewhere,11 were education about hypertension risk factors, along with specific mindfulness modules focused on mindful awareness of diet, physical activity, medication adherence, alcohol consumption, stress, and social support for behavior change. MB‐BP builds a foundation of mindfulness skills (eg, meditation, yoga, self‐awareness, attention control, and emotion regulation) through the MBSR curriculum. MB‐BP directs those skills toward participants' adhering to behaviors that can lower BP (Figure S1).11 MB‐BP participants have their BP and hypertension risk factors directly assessed at baseline and are provided with this information along with the recommended best practices and national health standards for BP control. MB‐BP encourages participants to explore personal readiness for change in the different hypertension lifestyle behaviors and trains participants to use mindfulness practices to engage with those behaviors that they choose. MB‐BP was led by qualified MBSR instructors with expertise in CVD cause, treatment, and prevention. They were further trained and certified to teach MB‐BP. Classes were provided in‐person for the first 10 cohorts (n=173), whereas the final 2 cohorts (n=28) began in‐person and shifted to live online via Zoom because of the COVID‐19 pandemic. Classes were held in Providence, Rhode Island, at Brown University, and at a local community health center located in a low‐income, urban neighborhood. Intervention group participants also received a home BP device (Omron, model BP786N) with an appropriately sized cuff, training in home BP monitoring,17 and, if office BP was ≥140/90 mm Hg, notification of primary care physicians about their BP results; those without a primary care physician were offered assistance finding a primary care physician within the constraints of their health insurance.

Participants assigned to the enhanced usual care group received the same home BP device, training in home BP monitoring, and option for referral to primary care as participants in the intervention group. They also received an educational brochure about high BP publicly available from the American Heart Association (product code 50‐1731). Control group patients did not receive any mindfulness training as part of the study.

Treatment fidelity strategies were performed in accordance with recommendations of the National Institutes of Health Behavior Change consortium, specifically ensuring treatment fidelity in study design, provider training, treatment delivery, receipt of treatment, and enactment of treatment skills,18 described elsewhere.11 Instructors were assessed for intervention fidelity and were required to maintain >90% adherence to the curriculum.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The prespecified primary outcome was unattended office SBP at 6‐month follow‐up, assessed according to American Heart Association guidelines, detailed elsewhere.11, 19 BP was assessed using a calibrated Omron HEM‐705CPN automated BP monitor (Lake Forest, IL) with established validity, in a participant assessment room at the Brown University School of Public Health.20 BP was assessed during the baseline assessment and at 3‐ and 6‐month follow‐up. The mean of the second and third BP readings at each assessment was used for analyses, following best practices.21

Key secondary outcomes assessed at baseline and at 3 and 6 months included measures of health behaviors, antihypertensive use, perceived stress, and mindfulness. Physical activity during the previous week was measured using the International Physical Activity Questionnaire as total metabolic equivalent task (MET) minutes per week of physical activity and time spent in sedentary sitting activities.22 DASH‐consistent diet was assessed using the Harvard 163‐item 2007 Grid Food Frequency Questionnaire23 and coding of DASH diet adherence using methods developed by Folsom et al.24 Body mass index (kg/m2) was calculated by weight and height obtained from participants wearing light clothing without shoes, using a calibrated stadiometer (SECA, Hamburg, Germany) and weighing scale (SECA, model 22089) operated by trained technicians. Alcohol consumption was assessed via a modified Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Behavioral Factor Surveillance System Questionnaire, showing concurrent validity with other nationally representative survey measures.25 Antihypertensive medication use data (type, dose, and frequency) were collected directly from participants' medication bottles and confirmed with participants at assessments. Increases in antihypertensive medication dose or frequency from baseline to follow‐up were coded as “increase in antihypertensive medication use”; decreases were coded as “decrease in antihypertensive medication use.” Stress was assessed using the 10‐item Perceived Stress Scale with established validity and reliability.26 Mindfulness levels were assessed using the validated Five‐Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire.27

We systematically measured adverse events, including calculating clinically significant or reliable deteriorations in anxiety symptoms (assessed via the Beck Anxiety Inventory28) and depression symptoms (measured using the Center for Epidemiology Studies Depression Scale Revised),29 using the Reliable Change Index.30, 31 Furthermore, we monitored serious adverse events and physical injuries through at‐minimum‐monthly online safety checks. All adverse events were documented and reported in accordance with the data safety monitoring plan, including reporting all serious adverse events to the study principal investigator and the data safety monitoring board chair.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: For statistical power considerations, an MBSR meta‐analysis showed a 6.6‐mm Hg between‐group difference in office SBP at immediate follow‐up.10 A recent meta‐analysis of RCTs showed that a 5‐mm Hg SBP reduction resulted in a 10% lowering of major cardiovascular events, so that effect size is clinically relevant.32 Power analyses were based on the difference in mean t‐test results.33 We assumed a nominal level (2‐tailed) of 0.05 and an SD of 13 mm Hg in both groups.11 For a power of 80%, the required sample sizes for SBP differences of 6 or 7 mm Hg were of 74 or 55 per group, respectively. With ≈100 participants in each group, the power was adequate assuming effect sizes of ≥6 mm Hg, with an anticipated dropout rate of 20%.

We used generalized estimating equations to evaluate the effect of MB‐BP on the outcomes compared with the control at 3 and 6 months using an identity link and autoregressive covariance structure.34 Unadjusted analyses were prespecified, as there are risks for covariate adjustment, making the models less precise and inducing bias, particularly when adjusting for the primary outcome at baseline.35, 36, 37 When there are no covariate differences between the groups, as is the case in this study, it is appropriate not to perform covariate adjustment. However, although there is debate, we also recognize recommendations to perform analyses adjusted for the strata used to randomize participants in (ie, sex and BP status described in Blinding and Randomization section).38 As such, we present sensitivity analyses adjusting for the randomization strata variables so that readers have access to findings from both approaches.

To assess the degree to which the group cohorts became similar to each other, we calculated intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) within cohorts recruited in the study, separated by group at baseline (before group allocation), and at 3‐ and 6‐month follow‐up. Furthermore, as a measure of adverse events, the Reliable Change Index was used to calculate the percentage of participants with reliable deterioration, reliable improvement, and no reliable change in anxiety and depression symptoms.30, 31

Analyses were performed as intention to treat. We analyzed all participants with data regardless of whether they completed the MB‐BP or control programs. For example, of the 25 participants who had at least 2 absences from the MB‐BP program, 13 (52%) took part in the 6‐month follow‐up assessments and were included in analyses. Of the 15 participants who withdrew/discontinued MB‐BP, 5 took part in the 6‐month follow‐up assessments and were included in analyses. This complete case analysis is the main outcome analysis. We performed sensitivity analyses using multiple imputation. Predictive mean matching based on 14 baseline variables (eg, mean SBP, mean DBP, 10‐item Perceived Stress Scale score, Five‐Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire score, International Physical Activity Questionnaire score, DASH diet score, body mass index, age, race and ethnicity, and sex) was used to impute missing SBP values at 6 months within each study arm.39 Fifty imputations were generated, and generalized estimating equation analysis was performed in each. Further sensitivity analyses restricted analyses to participants who were not affected by the COVID‐19 pandemic during the time of the study. All analyses were performed using SAS version 9.4 (SAS Inc, Cary, NC) with the exception of the multiple imputation that was performed in R version 4.2.2 using the mice package 1.40 To minimize the possibility of unintentionally sharing information that can be used to re‐identify private information, a subset of the data generated for this study is available at the Open Science Framework and can be accessed at doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/86UCD.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The sample comprised 58.7% women, 81.1% non‐Hispanic White race and ethnicity, 51.7% with a college degree, and an average age of 59.5 years (range, 22–84 years). Mean SBP was 138.5 (SD, 13.2) mm Hg, and 67.3% of participants were taking antihypertensive medication. There were no significant baseline differences between MB‐BP and control groups (Table 1) in demographics, BP, mindfulness, perceived stress, or health behaviors. Participants with complete or incomplete data were also similar in these variables, except for physical activity in participants with complete data (4723 MET min/wk; SD, 4421 MET min/wk) versus missing follow‐up data (6463 MET min/wk; SD, 5635 MET min/wk), recognizing high statistical variance in this variable (Table S2).

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics Table for MB‐BP Group (n=101) and Control Group (n=100)

tr.td: First degree relative with hypertension, n (%)

fn.p: DASH, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension; and FFMQ, Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire.

Participants who stated they were races/ethnicities other than the described options self‐identified as follows. MB‐BP group: Asian/Caucasian mix (n=1), South Asian (n=1), Jewish (n=1), and English/Scottish (n=2). Control group: Cape Verdean (n=3), Jewish (n=1), and did not further disclose (n=1).

sec.p: The Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) flow diagram is shown in Figure 1. There were 201 participants randomized to either MB‐BP (n=101) or the enhanced usual care group (n=100). Ninety‐nine of the 101 participants assigned to MB‐BP received the intervention, whereas all 100 assigned to the control group were provided the enhanced usual care components. Eighty‐four of the 101 MB‐BP participants (83.2%) attended at least 7 of the 10 MB‐BP class sessions. The most common reason provided for discontinuing the intervention was because of health problems unrelated to the course (n=5); details are in Figure 1. Loss‐to‐follow‐up rates across the 2 groups were similar, with 17.8% (n=18) of MB‐BP participants discontinuing the study versus 17.0% (n=17) of control group participants. With the research study occurring during the years 2017 to 2020 and the COVID‐19 pandemic becoming a high‐risk event in the United States shortly after the last round of enrollment (February/March 2020), all participants completed baseline assessments and began MB‐BP before COVID‐19. However, the pandemic forced a pivot to online delivery of MB‐BP and shut down in‐person assessments (including BP). This prohibited the ability to collect 6‐month clinical measures (eg, office SBP) on 31 of our 201 enrolled participants and resulted in 14 of the 101 MB‐BP participants receiving a hybrid course (ie, in‐person classes were moved to Zoom delivery). For analyses on the in‐person assessed outcomes (eg, BP), sample sizes were 150 (77 MB‐BP and 73 control) at 3 months and 132 (68 MB‐BP and 64 control) at 6 months of follow‐up. The MB‐BP intervention was taught by 3 certified instructors, teaching 41, 33, and 27 participants.

caption.title: CONSORT flow diagram for participants randomized to MB‐BP or enhanced usual care control.
caption.p: CONSORT indicates Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials and MB‐BP, Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction.

sec.p: Primary outcome analyses showed a 5.3 (95% CI, −8.7 to −2.0; P=0.002) mm Hg reduction in unattended office SBP at 3‐month follow‐up and 5.9 (95% CI, −9.1 to −2.8; P<0.001) at 6‐month follow‐up. There was a between‐group difference of 2.8 mm Hg (95% CI, −7.1 to 1.5 mm Hg; P=0.21) from baseline at 3‐month follow‐up and a between‐group difference of 4.5 mm Hg (95% CI, −9.0 to −0.1 mm Hg; P=0.045; Figure 2) by 6‐month follow‐up, in prespecified unadjusted analyses. In post hoc analyses that adjusted for the BP and sex strata that participants were randomized within, there was a between‐group difference of 4.3 mm Hg (95% CI, −8.7 to 0.1 mm Hg; P=0.056) at 6‐month follow‐up. Sensitivity analyses using multiple imputation showed slightly larger between‐group effect sizes (−5.3 mm Hg; 95% CI, −10.9 to 0.2 mm Hg; P=0.059). In underpowered sensitivity analyses evaluating data obtained in participants who either (1) received in‐person MB‐BP before the COVID‐19 pandemic (n=173) or (2) received hybrid in‐person/online MB‐BP during the COVID‐19 pandemic (n=28), findings demonstrated effect sizes that were in the same directions for both subsamples at 6‐month follow‐up (Table S3).

caption.title: Effects of 8‐week MB‐BP program vs enhanced usual care control on systolic blood pressure over 6 months of follow‐up, using prespecified unadjusted generalized estimating equations.
caption.p: Error bars represent SEM. *P<0.05, between‐group difference. MB‐BP indicates Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction.

sec.p: DBP findings for MB‐BP versus control showed no differences between groups at 3 months (−1.1 mm Hg [95% CI, −3.7 to 1.4 mm Hg]; P=0.39) or 6 months (0.3 mm Hg [95% CI, −2.5 to 3.1 mm Hg]; P=0.84) in adjusted analyses.

In exploratory evaluations for the effects of MB‐BP versus control on plausible mechanisms (Table 2), mindfulness was significantly impacted by MB‐BP compared with control (7.3 Five‐Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire score difference [95% CI, 3.0–11.6 Five‐Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire score difference]; P<0.001). Notably, control group participants were asked whether, since enrolling in the study, they engaged in any type of mindfulness practice on their own independent of the program. Of the control participants, 31.5% reported that they had engaged in mindfulness practices, which could lead to some bias toward the null. There were significant between‐group differences at 6 months on sedentary activity (−350.8 sitting min/wk [95% CI, −636.5 to −65.1 sitting min/wk]; P=0.02). Although MB‐BP effects were in beneficial directions for other risk factors, including DASH diet score, perceived stress, physical activity, body mass index, antihypertensive medication use, and alcohol consumption, statistical variance was higher (P values ranging from 0.05 to 0.70; Table 2). For example, some evidence of effects on physical activity (P=0.12), perceived stress (P=0.05), and DASH diet (P=0.08) was demonstrated with clinically relevant effect sizes.41

caption.p: Differences at 3 and 6 Months in Health Behaviors, Antihypertensive Medication Use, Perceived Stress, and Mindfulness for Participants in the MB‐BP Group Versus the Enhanced Usual Care Control Group, in Prespecified Unadjusted Analyses, and in Post Hoc Analyses Adjusted for Stratification Variables Used in Randomizing Participants (ie, Sex and BP Category)

tr.td: Increase in antihypertensive use, odds of increased use
Decrease in antihypertensive use, odds of decreased use
Increase in antihypertensive use, odds of increased use
Decrease in antihypertensive use, odds of decreased use

fn.p: BMI indicates body mass index; BP, blood pressure; DASH, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension; FFMQ, Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire; MB‐PB, Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction; and MET, metabolic equivalent task.

sec.p: Interestingly, although most participants did not change their antihypertensive medication use, and antihypertensive medication use was included in the curriculum as a skillful approach to reduce BP, participants who received MB‐BP had 29% lower odds of increasing their use of antihypertensive medication (odds ratio [OR], 0.71 [95% CI, 0.20–2.52]) and 20% higher odds of decreasing their antihypertensive medication use (OR, 1.20 [95% CI, 0.31–4.72]) compared with the control group (Table 2). The 95% CIs are wide for these estimates, which should be kept in mind when interpreting the clinical significance. However, despite the generally decreased use of antihypertensive medications in the MB‐BP group (recognizing lower medication use would have an upward influence on BP), SBP was lowered with clinically relevant effect sizes in the MB‐BP compared with the control group.

To evaluate whether group cohort dynamics (eg, peer effects in MB‐BP subjects participating in the in‐person groups together) influenced findings, ICC analyses demonstrated no group cohort correlations in the control group (ICC values of −6.0%, 0.0%, and 0.0% at baseline and 3‐ and 6‐month follow‐up, respectively), and indications of some group cohort correlations in the MB‐BP group (ICC values of −7.0%, 9.2%, and 2.6%, respectively).

For adverse events, Reliable Change Index analyses demonstrated, by 6‐month follow‐up, reliable deterioration in anxiety symptoms and depression symptoms in 3.7% and 6.2% of MB‐BP group participants, respectively, and reliable improvements in 12.4% and 14.8% of MB‐BP group participants, respectively (Figure 3). There was evidence of lesser improvement and greater deterioration for anxiety and depression in the control group by 6‐month follow‐up (Figure 3). There were 8 serious adverse events observed, with 4 in the control group and 4 in the MB‐BP group, during the 6 months of follow‐up. Adverse events from physical injuries were also equal across the study groups (n=8 per group). None of the serious adverse events or physical injuries were found to be related to study involvement.

caption.title: Percentage of participants with a reliable deterioration and improvement from baseline to 3‐ and 6‐month follow‐up for depression symptoms (assessed via the Centers for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale Revised) (A) and anxiety symptoms (assessed via the Beck Anxiety Inventory) (B).
caption.p: Findings are shown for participants randomized to the MB‐BP group vs the control group. MB‐BP indicates Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this largest RCT to date comparing an adapted mindfulness training intervention (MB‐BP) with an enhanced usual care control for individuals with elevated office BP, we found that MB‐BP was associated with a 5.9 (95% CI, −8.7 to −2.0) mm Hg reduction in BP from baseline to 6 months and outperformed the enhanced usual care control group by 4.5 (95% CI, −9.0 to −0.1) mm Hg in prespecified unadjusted analyses, and 4.3 (95% CI, −8.7 to 0.1) mm Hg in post hoc analyses adjusted for baseline randomization strata (ie, sex and hypertension status). Given that a recent meta‐analysis of 344 716 participants showed that a 5‐mm Hg reduction in SBP translated into a 10% lowering of major cardiovascular events in RCTs, these findings are clinically relevant.32

Exploratory mechanistic analyses showed that the MB‐BP intervention resulted in a substantial improvement in mindfulness compared with control (P<0.001). Plausible mechanisms with evidence that they were impacted by MB‐BP were sedentary activity (P=0.02), DASH diet (P=0.08), and perceived stress (P=0.05), recognizing a larger sample size may be needed for fully powered investigations on mechanisms that have small‐to‐medium effects. It is important to recognize that participants were not selected on these health behaviors, and not all needed to change every one of these behaviors (ie, floor effects). Future adequately powered analyses focused on participants who had poor levels of health behaviors targeted by MB‐BP at baseline will provide further insights on the role of MB‐BP in influencing behavior change.

Mindfulness‐based programs tested to date for participants with high BP have been almost entirely MBSR.10, 42 MBSR trains mindfulness skills and focuses on stress reduction, but unlike MB‐BP, has minimal explicit addressing of hypertension education, diet, physical activity (other than yoga), alcohol consumption, or medication adherence. Our findings were consistent with a meta‐analysis of the effect of MBSR on BP in 6 RCTs, which showed a 6.6‐mm Hg (95% CI, 1.5–11.7) difference between groups at follow‐up (sample size ranged from 30–56 per study).10 The studies included in this meta‐analysis were of low to moderate quality, typically with brief follow‐up periods.10 The current study used rigorous unattended office BP measurements, blinded outcome assessors, blinded statistician, a prespecified primary outcome, and 6 months of follow‐up time, thereby advancing the evidence that mindfulness training may improve BP control.

Informed by stakeholder interviews, we hypothesized that adapting MBSR to participants with high BP would improve acceptability of the program by participants and boost effects on BP.11 Our prior single‐arm trial showed good acceptability and a reduction of 6.1 mm Hg (P=0.008) at 1‐year follow‐up.11 The current study's findings are consistent with the single‐arm pilot MB‐BP study but now replicate findings in a phase 2 RCT.

ICC analyses suggested potential impact of the MB‐BP group cohorts on SBP, with 9.2% of the variance in SBP at 3‐month follow‐up, shortly after the program finished, and 2.6% at 6‐month follow‐up. Contemporary mindfulness‐based program teacher training emphasizes group factors, such as cultivating an environment to facilitate learning, including participants learning from each other.43 The group and peer support may be part of the active elements of the intervention.44, 45, 46

Recent systematic reviews of behavioral interventions to lower BP, having at least moderate levels of evidence using the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation, show mean reductions of SBP from physical activity, diet, weight loss, and alcohol interventions of 2 to 9 mm Hg SBP in intervention versus control.47, 48 This suggests the effects sizes of MB‐BP are comparable to other specific behavior change interventions. MB‐BP may offer a unique approach to improve BP control that could improve adherence for some of the 46% of Americans who have hypertension,3 of which >75% is uncontrolled despite the evidence on lifestyle intervention effectiveness.4 Although effect sizes for MBSR are mixed but somewhat comparable to MB‐BP in studies to date,10, 11, 48 a future comparative effectiveness study that randomized participants to MBSR versus MB‐BP to determine relative acceptability, effectiveness, and cost‐effectiveness between the 2 programs would provide more definitive findings of the added benefit of the adaptations made to the standard MBSR protocol. Further key next steps are replication of MB‐BP findings by independent groups and a multisite phase 3 trial that focuses on more generalizable participant samples with longer follow‐up time.

This study had several limitations. First, the follow‐up time was 6 months; the durability of intervention effects are not known, although our prior single‐arm study demonstrated significant improvements through 1‐year follow‐up.11 Second, the high proportion of well‐educated White participants reduced generalizability, but this program may be a viable way of introducing health education in underserved populations in a way more specific to BP than MBSR alone. Cardiovascular risk is worrisome in non‐White groups in the United States49, 50 and developing content that reflects the experiences of these communities is often difficult. However, systematic efforts to adapt mindfulness programs51 to include cultural content in the components of MP‐BP are moving forward in non‐White communities, including by our team.52 In this context, mindfulness provides a structure where cultural expression is blended into the class design to provide participants more meaning and connection to the intervention and increase the likelihood of participation in the program. The prior single arm MB‐BP trial was 4.1% non‐White and 91.8% college educated. To increase diversity in the subsequent RCT, we partnered with a health center located in a lower‐income, more racially diverse urban neighborhood, which likely contributed to our sample being 18.9% non‐White and 72.6% college educated for the current RCT. We recognize there is still a long way to go to increase diversity and have a grant focused on cocreating MB‐BP with a Native American tribal nation to assess effects in this racial group. Single clinical trials each contribute to the evidence base, but it will take a collection of clinical trials to understand the fuller picture of if, how, and for whom MB‐BP works. Third, this study meta‐analyzed data across 2 previously unanalyzed clinical trials that preregistered 3 primary outcomes (SBP, DASH diet score, and multidimensional assessment of interoceptive awareness). The SBP outcome is emphasized here, and another article will report on the other 2 outcomes in detail.16 Recognizing a Bonferroni correction for 3 outcomes would lower the P‐value threshold to 0.017 for statistical significance, replication of these findings with SBP named as the sole primary outcome will improve confidence in making inferences. Fourth, although office‐assessed SBP predicts cardiovascular events and mortality, and several studies showed that BP measured with automatic office BP measures (versus the in‐person auscultatory method) are closer to awake out‐of‐office BP levels measured with ambulatory BP monitoring, it will be important for future studies to evaluate impacts of MB‐BP on home BP and 24‐hour ambulatory BP outcomes, which have strong predictive validity for cardiovascular events and mortality.53 Fifth, using the current study design, it was not possible to determine which components of MB‐BP were most important for improving BP. Future dismantling studies can answer this question.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study demonstrated a clinically significant reduction in SBP comparable to many behavioral interventions for BP.47 Given the program uses mindfulness training integrated with modifiable determinants of BP, it may offer an appealing approach to help control BP of the 46% of Americans with hypertension,3 of which >75% is uncontrolled.2, 4, 5 Given hypertension is a primary cause of CVD, and that CVD is the number 1 cause of mortality in the United States and worldwide,1 these findings could have implications on improved BP control.2

sec.title: Sources of Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Institutes of Health Science of Behavior Change Common Fund Program through an award administered by the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (UH2AT009145 and UH3AT009145).

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Dr Loucks developed Mindfulness‐Based Blood Pressure Reduction (MB‐BP) and was one of the 3 MB‐BP instructors for this study. He does not receive financial compensation related to MB‐BP. Conditions were put in place to limit the potential bias of Dr Loucks on study data interpretation. For example, the primary outcome was preregistered on ClinicalTrials.gov. Dr Loucks did not have access to the master data file. He also did not perform the statistical analyses, which were performed by an independent blinded data analyst (Matthew M. Scarpaci). Dr Britton is an Mindfulness‐Based Stress Reduction and Mindfulness‐Based Cognitive Therapy teacher and has received financial compensation for this role. Dr Britton is the founder of Cheetah House, a Rhode Island nonprofit organization that provides information about meditation‐related difficulties, individual consultations, and support groups, as well as educational trainings to meditation teachers, clinicians, educators, and mindfulness providers. This interest has been disclosed to and is being managed by Brown University, in accordance with its Conflict of Interest and Conflict of Commitment policies. The remaining authors have no disclosures to report.
